segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Increase scheduling priority security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Increase scheduling priority security policy setting.

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Increase scheduling priority security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Increase scheduling priority security policy setting.

segment.source: This policy setting determines which user accounts can increase the base priority class of a process.
segment.target: This policy setting determines which user accounts can increase the base priority class of a process.

segment.source: It is not a privileged operation to increase relative priority within a priority class.
segment.target: It is not a privileged operation to increase relative priority within a priority class.

segment.source: This user right is not required by administrative tools that are supplied with the operating system, but it might be required by software development tools.
segment.target: This user right is not required by administrative tools that are supplied with the operating system, but it might be required by software development tools.

segment.source: Specifically, this security setting determines which accounts can use a process with Write Property access to another process to increase the run priority that is assigned to the other process.
segment.target: Specifically, this security setting determines which accounts can use a process with Write Property access to another process to increase the run priority that is assigned to the other process.

segment.source: A user with this privilege can change the scheduling priority of a process through the Task Manager user interface.
segment.target: A user with this privilege can change the scheduling priority of a process through the Task Manager user interface.

segment.source: Allow the default value, Administrators, as the only account responsible for controlling process scheduling priorities.
segment.target: Allow the default value, Administrators, as the only account responsible for controlling process scheduling priorities.

segment.source: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesUser Rights Assignment
segment.target: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesUser Rights Assignment

segment.source: By default this setting is Administrators on domain controllers and on stand-alone servers.
segment.target: By default this setting is Administrators on domain controllers and on stand-alone servers.

segment.source: The following table lists the actual and effective default policy values.
segment.target: The following table lists the actual and effective default policy values.

segment.source: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.
segment.target: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.

segment.source: This section describes features, tools, and guidance to help you manage this policy.
segment.target: This section describes features, tools, and guidance to help you manage this policy.

segment.source: A restart of the computer is not required for this policy setting to be effective.
segment.target: A restart of the computer is not required for this policy setting to be effective.

segment.source: Any change to the user rights assignment for an account becomes effective the next time the owner of the account logs on.
segment.target: Any change to the user rights assignment for an account becomes effective the next time the owner of the account logs on.

segment.source: Settings are applied in the following order through a Group Policy Object (GPO), which will overwrite settings on the local computer at the next Group Policy update:
segment.target: Settings are applied in the following order through a Group Policy Object (GPO), which will overwrite settings on the local computer at the next Group Policy update:

segment.source: When a local setting is greyed out, it indicates that a GPO currently controls that setting.
segment.target: When a local setting is greyed out, it indicates that a GPO currently controls that setting.

segment.source: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.
segment.target: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.

segment.source: A user who is assigned this user right could increase the scheduling priority of a process to Real-Time, which would leave little processing time for all other processes and could lead to a denial-of-service condition.
segment.target: A user who is assigned this user right could increase the scheduling priority of a process to Real-Time, which would leave little processing time for all other processes and could lead to a denial-of-service condition.

segment.source: Verify that only Administrators have the Increase scheduling priority user right assigned to them.
segment.target: Verify that only Administrators have the Increase scheduling priority user right assigned to them.

segment.source: Restricting the Increase scheduling priority user right to members of the Administrators group is the default configuration.
segment.target: Restricting the Increase scheduling priority user right to members of the Administrators group is the default configuration.
